awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Translational Ecology for Undergraduates
awd_abstract_narration:
This REU Site award to the Cary Institute of Ecosystem Studies, located in Millbrook, NY, will support the training of 10 students for 12 weeks during the summers of 2016-2020. Students join the unique Cary community of 100 scientists and staff to gain first-hand experience in ecological research with a focus on Translational Ecology. The program interweaves: 1) Cutting Edge Independent Research - working closely with a mentor scientist students identify questions, design and carry out research, and then analyze and present results. 2) Reflective Practice and Training - students attend Scientific Writing and Statistics/R Workshops, as well as a course in Responsible Conduct of Research training. 3) Translation -- students participate in a Communication Workshop, and write "elevator speeches" and lay-friendly research summaries. The Forum on Translational Ecology showcases a diversity of careers and approaches to applying and translating ecology. In the Sharing Science Program, students teach ecology to youngsters and reflect on translation through education. Undergraduate freshmen, sophomores, juniors or first semester seniors apply on-line, and are selected by project directors with input from the mentor of their preferred project. Preference is given to students who stand to benefit most from participation. 

It is anticipated that a total of 50 students, primarily from schools with limited research opportunities, will be trained in the program over the 5-year period. Cary REU students contribute to the field of ecology through publications, presentations, and bringing new insights to the field. The program has significant impact on students' education and career. Nearly three quarters of past participants attended graduate school and 90% now work in science, education or an environment-related job.

A common web-based assessment tool used by all REU programs funded by the Division of Biological Infrastructure (Directorate for Biological Sciences) will be used to determine the effectiveness of the training program. Students complete other program surveys and respond to an automatic email sent via the NSF reporting system, and alumni are contacted every year to document longer-term outcomes. More information is available at http://www.caryinstitute.org/students/reu-program, or from PI: Dr. Alan R. Berkowitz, (845) 677-7600 x311, berkowitza@caryinstitute.org or Co-PI: Dr. Shannon LaDeau, (845) 677-7600 x204, ladeaus@caryinstitute.org

por.por_cntn:
Cary Institute - 2016-2023 REU Program Outcomes Report

The Cary Institute of Ecosystem Studies offered its Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program every summer from 1988-2022. The 2016-2022 program theme was Translational Ecology for the Undergraduate. It was directed by Alan Berkowitz (PI) and co-directed by Shannon LaDeau (co-PI), Stuart Findlay, Felicia Keesing and Sarah Batterman, with 48 mentors and co-mentors, and 63 students participating. The intensive 12-week summer program from 2016-2020 immersed 8-13 students (Figure 1) each summer in the highly interactive Cary research environment. The 2021 program engaged 5 students for 10 weeks, and 1 student participated in 2022. Both the 2020 and 2021 programs were fully virtual due to the Covid19 pandemic (Figure 2).

Working closely with mentor scientists (Figure 3) and each other (Figure 4), students delineated a question, designed and implemented projects, analyzed data, and gave presentations in a formal symposium. Students reflected on what it means to be a scientist, and learned about how ecology is translated through communication, application and education. Activities included discussions, seminars, field trips, a communications workshop, the Sharing Science program where the REU students taught youngsters from Poughkeepsie (Figure 5), a local Case Study, writing and data inquiry workshops, and a full-day career forum.

Intellectual Merit

The program contributed to the field of ecology, with 76 peer-reviewed publications, 43 with REU student lead authors. This includes 7 papers during the reporting period, 5 with REU student lead authors. In addition, final research papers from nearly all of the students were published by Cary Institute in 7 Undergraduate Research Reports (1988-2001) or asonline Undergraduate Ecology Research Reports (2002-on, http://www.caryinstitute.org/publications/).

Exemplary projects show the diversity, depth and excitement of the students’ contributions to ecology:

●        Sabrina Volponi (2018, Bridgewater  College), mentored by Kathie Weathers and Dave Richardson, did an elegant study of nitrogen additions in lakes, published in Limnology and Oceanography (Volponi et al. 2023).

●        Emma Castiblanco (2020, Haverford College), mentored by Peter Groffman, analyzed long-term data for nitrogen and chloride levels in an exurban stream published in the journal, Urban Ecosystems (Castiblano et al. 2023).

●        MyKenna Zettle (2020, University of Pittsburg Bradford), by Shannon LaDeau, studied mosquito ecology along an urban gradient, published in the Journal of Medical Entomology (Zettle et al. 2022).

We shared our innovative approaches to education with the field at REU PI meetings, conferences, workshops and seminars, and through leadership of the UWIN Undergraduate Research Program, the UFERN RCN, and the Critical Zone Collaborative Network REU Program.

Broader Impacts.

The program received 1781 applications from 2016-2022: 42% from students at schools with limited research opportunities, 17% from underrepresented minorities and 63% from women. The 63 students that participated 2016-2022 were represented by 51% underrepresented minorities, 73% female, 48% from schools with limited research opportunities, and over 20% first-generation college students. Cary REU students have gone on to diverse post-undergraduate pursuits (Figure 6). We have information about students’ post-program status for at least 4 years from participation for all but 11 of our 346 alumni. A full 90% of the employed alumni were in science or related jobs (53% in academia, 8% in consulting or industry, 16% in education; and 12% in health or veterinary sciences). At the time of our most recent alumni survey (2020), 63% had completed or were in graduate school and another 8% indicated their intention to pursue a graduate degree.

To probe for lasting legacies from participating in the IES/Cary REU program we asked alumni, What, if anything, about your current knowledge, skills, attitudes or activities is a legacy of your participation in the IES/Cary REU program? Among the legacies mentioned by 105 respondents were:

●        75 mentioned science practices, e.g., “I liked the way the Cary REU program fostered development of a scientific research project from start to finish. The project wasn't so successful, but that didn't really matter since I gained a much better understanding of the scientific method that I've carried with me since”.  

●        These included mentions of the program theme, translational ecology, e.g., “I also think that the program's focus on the importance of translational ecology and clear science communication is something I continue to strive for and often reflect upon”.  

●        34 mentioned attitudes, especially confidence, e.g., “I didn't feel confident or validated as a science student or researcher before Cary, but I most certainly did afterwards”. 

●        27 mentioned career impacts such as building a professional network and clarifying career paths, e.g., Literaly everything in my career is a result of having had access to this opportunity 20 years ago...I'm now tenured at an R1 and still work with some of the same collaborators I met as an undergrad (and later postdoc) at IES/Cary”.  

A new alumni survey will provide additional insights into the broader impacts of the Cary REU Program.

 


Last Modified: 11/20/2023
Modified by: Alan R Berkowitz

Images (1 of )
  • 5. Each year, Cary REU students engage youngsters from nearby Poughkeepsie in ecological discovery in the Sharing Science program on the Cary campus. Shown here are students from the 2016 program.
    Pamela Freeman
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Alan R Berkowitz
    Cary REU Student Sharing Science
  • 1. Each year Cary Institute welcomed 8-13 undergraduate students for an intensive 10-12 week program in independent research in ecology. They also learn about translating ecology through communication, application and education. Shown here is the 2017 group.
    Pamela Freeman
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Alan R Berkowitz
    Cary REU Students 2017
  • 2. The 2020 Cary REU program was entirely virtual due to the pandemic. Nonetheless, the students formed a close cohort with each other and strong relationships with their mentors, completed outstanding research projects, while also learning about translational ecology.
    Kevin Burgio
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Alan R Berkowitz
    Cary REU Virtual Student Group 2020
  • Most recent career status the 231 alumni among the 340 participants in the past 33 years for whom we have data. Excluded are students still in school (69), not employed (10), or missing (11). Science professions are shaded in green; education salmon; health professions blue; and non-science tan.
    Alan R Berkowitz
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Alan R Berkowitz
    Cary REU Alumni Status
  • Cary REU student in the 2018 program working with mentor Shannon LaDeau on a study of mosquito ecology using popcorn tub microcosms.
    Pamela Freeman
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Alan R Berkowitz
    Cary REU Student and Mentor
  • 4. Cary REU students often help each other with their research, building strong bonds and learning about different approaches to ecology. Shown here are three students in the 2017 program on a night-time fish sampling event at nearby Lake Minnewaska.
    Cary REU Program
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Alan R Berkowitz
    Cary REU Students Collaborating in Fish Sampling

● Sabrina Volponi (2018, Bridgewater College), mentored by Kathie Weathers and Dave Richardson, did an elegant study of nitrogen additions in lakes, published in Limnology and Oceanography (Volponi et al. 2023). 


● Emma Castiblanco (2020, Haverford College), mentored by Peter Groffman, analyzed long-term data for nitrogen and chloride levels in an exurban stream published in the journal, Urban Ecosystems (Castiblano et al. 2023).


● MyKenna Zettle (2020, University of Pittsburg Bradford), by Shannon LaDeau, studied mosquito ecology along an urban gradient, published in the Journal of Medical Entomology (Zettle et al. 2022).


We shared our innovative approaches to education with the field at REU PI meetings, conferences, workshops and seminars, and through leadership of the UWIN Undergraduate Research Program, the UFERN RCN, and the Critical Zone Collaborative Network REU Program.

● 75 mentioned science practices, e.g., I liked the way the Cary REU program fostered development of a scientific research project from start to finish. The project wasn't so successful, but that didn't really matter since I gained a much better understanding of the scientific method that I've carried with me since.
